title: What is the Nyquist (Shannon) sampling theorem? - Quora

response.answer_text: The sampling theorem is not by Nyquist. It was derived by Shannon. Nyquist’s theorem deals with the maximum signalling rate over a channel of given bandwidth. Since the results are similar, people often associate Nyquist’s name with the sampling theorem. But this is not correct. Hereafter, I will refer to the result as Shannon’s sampling theorem. Anyway, here goes: The Shannon sampling theorem can be understood by using the analogy of a rotating wheel.  Consider a wheel with eight spokes spaced 45 degrees apart.(you can choose any angular spacing you like, this is only an illustration.) Now suppose you rotate the spokes at 45 degrees per second in the anti-clockwise direction. Then it would take eight seconds for each spoke to return to its original position. Now you have a analog signal before your eyes(with your eyes being the recording instrument.) Now suppose you take a camera and take photos after 8 seconds, 16 seconds, 24 seconds and so on as you keep rotating the flywheel at 45 degrees/second. Now take a look at the photos. Do you see any difference? No. Each of the photographs shows the spokes in their original positions, even though they have rotated, because their final position is the same. This has happened because in the sampling period(8 seconds) an integral number of cycles of the wheel’s rotation can pass. What happens if you rotate the flywheel in the clockwise direction? Does it make any difference? No, because the spokes are still in their original positions at the end of the sampling period. Thus we discover an important constraint: A sampling period that covers an integral number of cycles of an analog phenomenon cannot detect phase(state) change. Lets try to improve upon this constraint.If you take the photos at a rate faster than 8 seconds, then perhaps you might be able to capture the movement of the spokes? Lets try taking photos at intervals of 4 seconds. In 4 seconds, the flywheel covers only a half cycle. So yes, you can detect rotations. But there is a glitch. What about the clockwise rotation? Are you able to distinguish between it and the anti-clockwise version? No. So this half cycle point represents a limiting condition. While we are able to distinguish between each clockwise rotation, we are not able to distinguish them form their anti-clockwise counterparts. Now lets try to improve upon this. Lets consider taking photos at a faster rate than 4 seconds. Say every 3 seconds. In 3 seconds, the flywheel covers only 135 degrees and whichever direction you rotate it clockwise or anti-clockwise, the rotation can be distinguished. This is the Shannon sampling theorem, that the sampling frequency should be greater than twice the maximum frequency of the original analog signal,failing which aliasing(phase/frequency ambiguity) will occur. A note about the naming of the ST: the “discovery” of the ST is attributed not only to Nyquist and Shannon, but also to Whittaker and Kotelnikov. Quoting Nyquist–Shannon sampling theorem - Wikipedia: “The name Nyquist–Shannon sampling theorem honors Harry Nyquist and Claude Shannon. The theorem was also discovered independently by E. T. Whittaker, by Vladimir Kotelnikov, and by others. It is thus also known by the names Nyquist–Shannon–Kotelnikov, Whittaker–Shannon–Kotelnikov, Whittaker–Nyquist–Kotelnikov–Shannon, and cardinal theorem of interpolation.” According to the Wikipedia article above, the pioneer was Whittaker who published the result in 1915. There is a link to the paper in the Wikipedia article. Besides the theoretical value of the ST, it has the merit of explaining aliasing (Aliasing - Wikipedia) and the drawbacks and “good” applications of this phenomenon, such as undersampling of bandpass signals (or bandlimited signals) to bring them to lower frequencies (to the baseband). This is also known as sampling of non-baseband signals and has important applications, such as in the “software defined radio” (see page 5 of http://www.sdradio.eu/doc/DgtlRcvrHbk43.pdf). Interesting extensions of the ST exist, such as the one for random sampling (regarding the sampling instant), at an average rate inferior to the Nyquist rate, defined has [math]f_N=f_{samp}/2[/math] in uniform sampling (with constant sampling interval [math]T_{samp}=1/f_{samp}[/math]). See http://label2.ist.utl.pt/vilela/Cursos/Sampling_And_SuperSL3.pdf and http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/1703843/?arnumber=1703843.

response.answer_text: You have a periodic analog signal, let’s say f(t). You can’t not store this signal in your computer as it is because one cannot simply save infinite number of functional values. However, when f(t) is band-limited (that is, the period is a finite number, let’s say Ts=1/Fs), you can perfectly reconstruct f(t) from 2Fs measurements per period of f(t) by doing something called sinc interpolation. In practice, to make sure f(t) is band-limited, we need to apply an anti-aliasing filter before sampling.

The Nyquist theorem says that when you digitize an analog signal of bandwidth W, the sampling frequency must be at least double (2W) (or the distance between samples is 1/2W) to guarantee reconstruction. For example, for speech bounded at 20 kHz, a typical sampling rate is 44.1 kHz. Nyquist–Shannon sampling theorem
The Nyquist theorem states that, in order to perfectly reconstruct a baseband signal with bandwidth W, you need to sample it at at least frequency 2W.
